value.title: Share Different Visual Pages with Different Security Groups in Power BI
value.excerpt: I have written a dozen of blogs and a book about Power BI row-level security and the security on the dataset. However, I always get this question that: "What if I want some people to see only a few pages of my report, and some others to see other pages?" or "How can I put security for different pages
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Iy1ZjToy-B8" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Showing Ranking in a Visual in Power BI using RANKX DAX function
value.excerpt: If you want to show the ranking in a Power BI visual, one way is to use a visual that supports that, such as a Ribbon chart. Another way, which is a more common way, is to write a calculation for rank, and RANKX is a DAX function that can help you with that. In this article and video, I explain how that
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/FCWVX8W1QZk" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: SUM vs SUMX What is the Difference of the two DAX Functions in Power BI
value.excerpt: Sum and Sumx are functions that often founded to be misleading for many Power BI users. As both functions are doing the aggregation, it seems a bit confusing what is the actual difference between these two. There are many blog posts and articles about each function. I always explain the difference with

value.title: What Do You Need to Implement Dynamic Row Level Security in Power BI
value.excerpt: I have explained in some videos about the RLS topic already. Through my consulting experience, however, I get the feeling that many people can’t easily move from static RLS to dynamic. If you know what are things you need to have the dynamic RLS implemented, it makes the whole process simple. So this

value.title: Analyzing a slow report query in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: Investigate a slow query in a Power BI report using DAX Studio, looking at the query plan and the server timings. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/ Optimizing DAX Workshop: https://www.sqlbi.com/p/optimizing-dax-video-course/

value.title: Controlling drillthrough in Excel PivotTables connected to Power BI or Analysis Services
value.excerpt: Learn how to customize the drillthrough experience in Excel PivotTables connected to Power BI datasets or Analysis Services databases. Article and download: https://sql.bi/726459?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt The definitive guide to DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/books/the-definitive-guide-to-dax-2nd-edition/?aff=yt

value.title: Creating a calculated table with DAX Studio

value.title: Customize default values for each user in Power BI reports
value.excerpt: Learn how to use calculation groups to define a default set of values for columns in your model. Different users can have different default values, and yet retain the full capability to select different values. Article and download: https://sql.bi/717242?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt

value.title: Differences between INT and CONVERT in DAX
value.excerpt: How do you convert a DAX expression into an integer value? There are small differences between INT and CONVERT in DAX that may end up returning different results in arithmetic expressions. Article and download: https://sql.bi/742452?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt

value.title: Displaying filter context in Power BI Tooltips

value.title: Filtering a measure in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: DAX Studio can evaluate one or more measures in a query. Marco Russo shows how to apply filters to a measure executed in DAX Studio. Continuous learning to improve your productivity!  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Introducing LOOKUPVALUE
value.excerpt: This video shows how to use LOOKUPVALUE, which is a handy function for any developer to have in their toolbelt. Article and download: https://sql.bi/670595?aff=yt Additional resources: Expanded tables (article): https://sql.bi/65647?aff=yt

value.title: Introducing Performance Analyzer in Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Performance Analyzer is the first diagnostic tool to find the slower parts of a report. Find the slowest DAX query before starting a deeper investigation using DAX Studio. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables
value.excerpt: This video describes how to use variables to optimize the performance of DAX expressions containing multiple instances of the same measure or the same sub-expression. There are two related articles and downloads: https://sql.bi/62887/?aff=yt (Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables) https://sql.bi/67786/?aff=yt

value.title: Sorting months in fiscal calendars in DAX
value.excerpt: This video shows a basic technique used to sort months according to a fiscal calendar, by using a couple of calculated columns and the “sort by column” feature of Power BI. Article and download: https://sql.bi/492713?aff=yt

value.title: Star schema or single table in Power BI
value.excerpt: Is it better to build a model as a regular star schema or as a single table in Power BI? The answer is clear: a star schema is always the best choice. This video analyzes the performance differences of the two approaches. Article and download: https://sql.bi/704257?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/qEWrYO1ioe0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Understanding the difference between LASTDATE and MAX in DAX
value.excerpt: This video explains why in many cases, MAX should be used instead of LASTDATE to search for the last date in a time period using DAX. Article and download: https://sql.bi/673766?aff=yt

value.title: Using ALLSELECTED in composite models
value.excerpt: Using ALLSELECTED with no arguments in a remote model later used in a composite model might produce unexpected results. In this video, we explain why ALLSELECTED requires special attention. Article and download: https://sql.bi/737377?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt

value.title: 5 New Features I Love – Coming Soon to Power BI

The next plan is called Power Platform Release Plan 2021 Wave 2. It takes a [...]Read More »

value.title: 5 Productivity Benefits of Tabular Editor 3
value.excerpt: Tabular Editor is a Power BI Tabular Modelling productivity tool developed by Daniel Otykier. I blogged about Version 2 of the Tabular Editor in this article here. The 3rd edition of Tabular Editor has just been released, and it is a major upgrade from version 2. TE 3 is not [...]Read More »

value.title: Build a P&L in Power BI Without Any DAX
value.excerpt: This is the third article where I have covered building a P&L in Power BI. My first 2 articles here and here focused on how to use the DAX language to solve some of the common problems with P&L reporting, such as adding sub totals into the visual, % of [...]Read More »

value.title: Building a Matrix with Asymmetrical Columns and Rows in Power BI

value.title: Building a P&L in Power BI – Part 2 (Percentages)
